G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19, and G.L. c. 223, §2, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the Somerville District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a72.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19, and G.L. c. 223, §2, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the Somerville District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a71.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, §1, because the events giving rise to this claim occurred in Somerville, Massachusetts.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty of reasonable care to maintain the premises in a safe condition and to protect her against dangers of which Defendant knew or should have known. See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurrence discussing the abandonment of common-law invitee/licensee distinctions and criticizing the continued separate treatment of trespassers. It does not articulate or affirm a specific rule that a landowner owes a business invitee a duty of reasonable care to maintain premises and protect against known or reasonably knowable dangers. Instead, it questions status-based classifications altogether. Thus, this excerpt does not support the specific business-invitee duty proposition cited.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 783‑84 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Defendant further had a duty under Massachusetts law to inspect and remedy hazards or, where immediate remediation was not possible, to warn invitees of such hazards. See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 783‑84 (2007); Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973).
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The proposition describes a general Massachusetts duty to inspect, remedy, or warn of hazards to invitees. Sheehan does not frame the duty in those general terms; instead, it refines the premises‑liability notice requirement by adopting the mode‑of‑operation approach for self‑service stores. The opinion discusses an owner’s duty to take reasonable precautions commensurate with foreseeable risks from its mode of operation, but it does not specifically state a separate, generalized duty to inspect and remedy hazards or to warn when immediate remediation is not possible.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, the adoption of the mode of operation approach will not modify the general rule governing premises liability requiring a plaintiff to prove that an owner had either actual or constructive notice of an unsafe condition on the premises. However, if a plaintiff proves that an unsafe condition on an owner’s premises exists that was reasonably foreseeable, resulting from an owner’s self-service business or mode of operation, and the plaintiff slips as a result of the unsafe condition, the plaintiff will satisfy the notice requirement… [T]he trier of fact [must determine] whether the owner took all necessary reasonable precautions commensurate with the risks inherent in a self-service method of operation to protect individuals from such foreseeable risks.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant further had a duty under Massachusetts law to inspect and remedy hazards or, where immediate remediation was not possible, to warn invitees of such hazards. See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 783‑84 (2007); Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: Oliveri expressly states the duty of one who controls business premises to use due care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition or at least to warn patrons of dangers the possessor knows or should know about. That is the same Massachusetts premises‑liability duty described in the proposition: to inspect and remedy hazards or, if they cannot be immediately remedied, to warn invitees. The opinion applies this standard in the context of a slip‑and‑fall on a stairway, directly supporting the cited proposition.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, **or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.**” 363 Mass. at 167.

Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.raw_text: Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560 (1955)
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.proposition: Defendant breached its duty of care by failing to timely clean or warn of the spilled milk despite actual or constructive notice of the dangerous condition. See Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560 (1955); Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988).
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses premises liability for a spill and holds that a store can be liable where, based on the condition and location of the substance and the presence of nearby employees, a jury could find the defendant should, in the exercise of reasonable care, have discovered and remedied the hazard. The court affirms that although there was no proof of actual knowledge, the evidence permitted an inference of constructive notice and a negligent failure to remove the substance or protect customers, which matches the proposition about breaching the duty of care by not timely cleaning or warning after notice.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance… We think that it could be found… that the presence of this ice cream on the floor and vestibule… constituted an appreciable danger… Some appreciable time must have elapsed also for the ice cream to have gotten into the condition it was in… [T]he jury were warranted in drawing an inference… that it had been on the… floor long enough to have been known of and removed before the accident.”

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.proposition: Defendant breached its duty of care by failing to timely clean or warn of the spilled milk despite actual or constructive notice of the dangerous condition. See Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560 (1955); Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988).
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.support_reasoning: This case is about an allegedly negligently maintained freight elevator, not a premises-liability slip-and-fall from spilled milk. The SJC ultimately holds that the defendant did not breach his duty because an ordinarily prudent person would not have been required to take the additional safety measures urged by the plaintiff. The opinion discusses landowner duty and obvious dangers, but it does not address or establish a rule about timely cleaning or warning of transient spills after actual or constructive notice; if anything, it rejects imposing additional duties where a risk is obvious and not shown to be foreseeable.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’… However, the defendant was ‘not obliged to supply a place of maximum safety, but only one which would be safe to a person who exercises such minimum care as the circumstances reasonably indicate.’ … It follows that the defendant’s failure to adopt either of those measures did not constitute negligence.”

Palmisciano v. Thomas, 56 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Palmisciano v. Thomas, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 522, 526 (2002)
Palmisciano v. Thomas, 56 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The employee’s statement that he had observed the spill “a few minutes ago” constitutes actual knowledge of the hazard, and Defendant’s failure to act promptly constitutes negligence. See Palmisciano v. Thomas, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 522, 526 (2002).
Palmisciano v. Thomas, 56 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The quoted Palmisciano v. Thomas opinion is a Juvenile Court termination-of-parental-rights case and does not concern premises liability, spills, employee knowledge of hazards, or negligence in failing to clean up a spill. The claimed proposition about an employee’s statement regarding a spill and corresponding negligence is unrelated to the issues actually decided in this opinion. The citation is therefore inaccurate and not supported by this case.
Palmisciano v. Thomas, 56 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: In this appeal, the significant issue is whether a Juvenile Court judge erred in admitting in evidence findings from a prior termination of parental rights decision (concerning three other children) in a subsequent termination of parental rights trial involving a newborn child. In the circumstances of this case, we find no error.

Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.raw_text: Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837, 842‑43 (1987)
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s conduct falls below the standard of care required by law for operators of business premises open to the public and violates its common‑law duty of reasonable maintenance. See Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837, 842‑43 (1987).
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.support_reasoning: The cited concurrence states that the risk of injury from negligent operation of another vehicle at a self-service station is inherent and obvious and that there is no duty to warn of such a danger. That directly undercuts, rather than supports, a claim that the defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care or violated a duty of reasonable maintenance on these facts. The opinion thus does not provide authority for the proposition that the defendant’s conduct breached its common-law duty; instead it finds no such duty to warn in this context.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger.”

Graves v. General Ins. Corp., 344 Mass..raw_text: Graves v. General Ins. Corp., 344 Mass. 505 (1962)
Graves v. General Ins. Corp., 344 Mass..proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered physical injuries, economic losses, and emotional distress. See Graves v. General Ins. Corp., 344 Mass. 505 (1962).
Graves v. General Ins. Corp., 344 Mass..case_name: Allied Building Credits, Inc. v. State Tax Commission
Graves v. General Ins. Corp., 344 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is a Massachusetts tax case about assessment of a corporate excise on a foreign corporation’s intangible assets. It does not involve negligence, causation, personal injury, economic loss, or emotional distress, nor does it discuss elements of a tort claim. Citing this case for the proposition that a defendant’s negligence proximately caused a plaintiff’s physical, economic, and emotional harms is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the decision’s holding or reasoning.
Graves v. General Ins. Corp., 344 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "The appellant (Allied) appealed to the Appellate Tax Board (the board) from the refusal of the State Tax Commission to abate a corporate excise tax assessed against it for the year 1955.... Allied’s appeal to this court presents the issue whether error was shown in respect of the action of the Commissioner of Corporations and Taxation in determining... the amount of a foreign corporation’s intangible assets employed in any business within the Commonwealth...."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a785.proposition: Massachusetts law expressly recognizes a plaintiff’s right to recover for pain and suffering, medical expenses, and lost wages proximately caused by a defendant’s negligence.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a76F.proposition: Massachusetts law expressly recognizes a plaintiff’s right to recover for pain and suffering, medical expenses, and lost wages proximately caused by a defendant’s negligence.

O'Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 401 Ma.raw_text: O'Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 401 Mass. 586 (1988)
O'Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 401 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts law expressly recognizes a plaintiff’s right to recover for pain and suffering, medical expenses, and lost wages proximately caused by a defendant’s negligence.
O'Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 401 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion is about causation standards in asbestos litigation and joint and several liability among multiple tortfeasors; it does not discuss or expressly recognize the categories of damages recoverable (pain and suffering, medical expenses, lost wages). While those types of damages are implicitly assumed in any personal injury/wrongful death case, this decision does not articulate or affirm a rule about a plaintiff’s right to recover them under Massachusetts law. Therefore it does not provide direct authority for the specific damages proposition stated.
O'Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 401 Ma.relevant_excerpt: We have said before, and we repeat, “that if two or more wrongdoers negligently contribute to the personal injury of another by their several acts, which operate concurrently, so that in effect the damages suffered are rendered inseparable, they are jointly and severally liable.” Chase v. Roy, 363 Mass. 402, 408 (1973). Burke v. Hodge, 217 Mass. 182, 184-185 (1914).

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s negligence was both the factual and legal cause of Plaintiff’s damages within the meaning of Restatement (Second) of Torts §431, as adopted in Massachusetts law.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses general negligence elements, including causation, but the live issue and holding are about duty and foreseeability, not about whether the defendant’s negligence was the factual and legal cause of the plaintiff’s damages. The court expressly leaves questions of breach, extent of damage, and causal relation to the jury, and does not apply or adopt Restatement (Second) of Torts § 431, nor does it hold that causation has been established in this case. Thus, the case does not support the proposition that defendant’s negligence was both the factual and legal cause of plaintiff’s damages under § 431.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions … to be the special province of the jury.”

Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.proposition: Even if some comparative negligence were found, her recovery would remain available under G.L. c. 231, §85 so long as her fault does not exceed that of Defendant.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, and explains that a plaintiff’s contributory negligence does not bar recovery unless it is greater than the combined negligence of the defendants, and otherwise only reduces damages proportionally. That is the same rule summarized in the proposition—that recovery remains available so long as plaintiff’s fault does not exceed defendant’s. The court applies this principle in holding that Colter’s conduct does not bar his negligence claim as a matter of law.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.). … The plaintiff's conduct is not viewed as the sole proximate cause of the injury and does not bar recovery completely unless the plaintiff is more than fifty per cent responsible for his or her own injuries.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a76B and 6C.proposition: Award statutory interest and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§6B and 6C;
